item.title: Algebraic Geometry
item.description: 14/05/2021 18:04# Chapter 1 Section 1 $Z(T)$ can be expressed as the common zeros of the finite set of polynomals $f_1, \cdots, f_r$. $A = k[x_1, \cdots, x_n]$ is a Noetherian ring. Every ideal in $A = k[x]$ is principle If $k$ is algebraically closed then $k$ is an infinite set. Example 1.1.3. Any nonempty open subset of an irreducible space is irreducible and dense Example 1.1.4. If $Y$ is an irreducible subset of $X$, then its closure $\bar{Y}$ in $X$ is also irreducible.

item.title: Euler Identity
item.description: The Beauty of Euler’s Identity Mathematics is a fascinating subject that constantly surprises us with its beauty and complexity. One of the most beautiful equations in mathematics is Euler’s identity, which relates five fundamental mathematical constants: \(e\), \(i\), \(\pi\), \(0\), and \(1\). It is often considered the most elegant equation in all of mathematics. The equation is given by: \[ e^{i\pi} + 1 = 0 \] This equation is remarkable for several reasons.
